filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of thirty-three of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. All take their subjects from the New Testament and have been added to the twenty Old Testament subjects published in March 2010 as “Illustrations to the Bible, c. 1780-1824,” under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings. This new group is presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
Blake executed most of these New Testament water colors c. 1800-05 for his patron Thomas Butts. The exceptions are The Whore of Babylon of 1809 and The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins in the Yale Center for British Art, datable to c. 1825. The subjects range from the childhood of Jesus to his ascension, the later history of his parents and one of his major followers, St. Paul, and a group of eight designs based on the Book of Revelation. While the illustrations of the life of Christ are fairly conventional in their subjects, in part because of the long tradition of picturing almost every event in the Gospels, individual motifs recall designs in Blake’s illuminated books and thus offer a window on Blake’s visual interpretation of the Bible. The illustrations of Revelation complement Blake’s intense engagement with apocalyptic events and images in his own poetry.
The selection of fifty-three biblical water colors now available in the Archive will be supplemented in the future with early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and will continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, such as Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objtitle.title: *Christ in the House of Martha and Mary: "But Martha Was Cumbered About Much Serving"*

objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, and water color

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1803-05; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 26 March 1852, lot 164 (£1.10s. to Charles Wentworth Dilke); given by Dilke in 1884 to the Victoria and Albert Museum.

desc.objtitle: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary: "But Martha Was Cumbered About Much Serving", Object 1 (Butlin 489)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work lower right with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The old mount, now removed, is inscribed "But Martha was cumbered about much serving," "Luke 10 ch: v. 41:st & 42" (cut off by the edge of the mat), and with a quotation from the biblical passage below the title. These mat inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This water color derives from Luke 10:38-42. In the left foreground sits Jesus, looking right in profile with his body twisted to face away slightly. He reclines with his bent left arm on a pillow, raising his right arm at 45 degrees to gesture to the figure to the right. Jesus's right knee is bent. He wears a gown and has a halo-like aura around his head. He has long, curly hair and a beard. His mouth is slightly open. He may be speaking. His right foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown. The figure second from the left in the foreground is a kneeling or crouching female. She has long, curly hair and wears a gown. She faces left and slightly forward, looking down. Her legs are bent underneath her and her left arm is bent and rests on a cushion or pillow. Her right arm is bent upward and her right hand rests on her head. She may represent Mary (see Luke 10:39). The figure on the far right in the foreground is female, facing left and looking down. She may represent Martha (see Luke 10:40). She wears a gown and has long hair pulled up in a bun. Her left arm is at her side and in her left hand she holds a plate. Her right arm is bent, with the palm out. Her mouth is slightly open. She may be talking. Jesus and Mary in the foreground sit on a cushioned bench or seats, covered in cloth. They each rest on a pillow. In the midground is a table, laid with a tablecloth. On the table are two empty plates or platters, a goblet possibly filled to the brim with wine, and two plates or platters with fruit (including grapes with leaves on them). In the background, in the top corners of the design, hang curtains or draperies. Alternatively, the scene may take place in a tent. At the top center of the design is a menorah with seven leafy branches and lit candles. In the background of the design sit three figures. The leftmost figure is of indeterminable gender, wears a gown and may have curly hair. He or she faces forward and slightly right and has his or her mouth open. He or she may be speaking and also may be looking at Jesus. The middle figure of this group is a gowned old man with long hair and a long beard. He faces forward and looks to the left at Jesus. The rightmost figure is a young man with short, curly hair. He wears a gown and faces right, looking left at Jesus.

component.illusobjdesc: In the left foreground sits Jesus, looking right and with his body twisted to face away slightly. He reclines with his bent left arm on a pillow, raising his right arm at 45 degrees to gesture to the figure to the right. His right knee is bent. He wears a gown and has a halo-like aura around his head. He has long, curly hair and a beard. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking. His right foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown.

The figure second from the left in the foreground is a kneeling or crouching female. She has long, curly hair and wears a gown. She faces left and slightly forward, looking down. Her legs are bent underneath her and her left arm is bent and rests on a cushion or pillow. Her right arm is bent upward and her right hand rests on her head. She may represent Mary (see Luke 10:39).

The figure on the far right in the foreground is female, facing left and looking down. She may represent Martha (see Luke 10:40). She wears a gown and has long hair pulled up in a bun. Her left arm is at her side and in her left hand she holds a plate. Her right arm is bent, with the palm out. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be speaking.
Jesus and Mary sit on a cushioned bench or seats, covered in cloth. They each rest on a pillow. The cushion beneath Jesus has a leaf-like pattern.

In the midground is a table, laid with a tablecloth. On the table are two empty plates or platters, a goblet possibly filled to the brim with wine, and two plates or platters with fruit (including grapes with leaves on them).
In the background, in the upper corners of the design, hang curtains or draperies. Alternatively, the scene may take place in a tent.
At the top center of the design is a menorah with seven leafy branches and lit candles.

In the background, on the far side of the table, sit three figures. The leftmost figure is of indeterminable gender. He or she wears a gown and may have curly hair; faces forward and slightly right and has his or her mouth open, with its right arm bent. He or she may be speaking and also may be looking at Jesus.

In the background, on the far side of the table, sit three figures. The middle figure of this group is a gowned old man with long hair and a curly beard. He faces forward and looks to the left at Jesus, but his body is slightly twisted to face right. He may lean on his bent right arm, while his left arm is at his side.

In the background, on the far side of the table, sit three figures. The rightmost figure is a young man with short, curly hair. He wears a gown and faces right, looking left at Jesus. His right arm may be bent. He may be resting on a cushion or pillow, one edge of which is visible to the left and just above the far edge of the table.
The scene takes place in a room, possibly with a patterned carpet on the floor. Alternatively, the scene may take place in a tent.
